title: Are You A Classical Or Romantic Voter?

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the two fundamental electoral types that people can be divided into?

options.label: A
options.text: Right-wing and left-wing

options.label: B
options.text: Conservative and liberal

options.label: C
options.text: Romantic and classical

options.label: D
options.text: Democratic and republican

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following best describes the romantic voter's attitude towards change?

options.label: A
options.text: They are cautious and prefer gradual change

options.label: B
options.text: They are impatient and believe in taking bold action

options.label: C
options.text: They are indifferent to change and prefer the status quo

options.label: D
options.text: They are opposed to change and prefer tradition

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the classical voter's view of human nature?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe humans are inherently good and can be trusted

options.label: B
options.text: They believe humans are flawed but can be improved through education

options.label: C
options.text: They believe humans have deeply dangerous impulses and need to be contained

options.label: D
options.text: They believe humans are neutral and can be shaped by their environment

multiple-choice.question: How do romantic voters approach the issue of blame and responsibility?

options.label: B
options.text: They are quick to assign blame and believe in holding individuals accountable

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that blame is irrelevant and focus on finding solutions

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that blame is a necessary step towards justice and righteousness

options.label: A
options.text: They believe in showing strength and assertiveness to ensure national security

options.label: B
options.text: They believe in building alliances and cooperating with other nations

options.label: C
options.text: They believe in avoiding actions that could upset or alarm neighbors

options.label: D
options.text: They believe in isolationism and avoiding international engagement

title: How the rubber glove was invented | Moments of Vision 4 - Jessica Oreck

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem faced by Caroline Hampton, the scrub nurse under Dr. William Halsted?

options.label: B
options.text: She was developing a severe reaction to the strong disinfectants used to scour her hands and arms before surgery.

options.label: C
options.text: She was experiencing eye strain from the bright lights in the operating room.

options.label: D
options.text: She was having trouble with the hospital's uniform policy.

options.label: A
options.text: The hospital's administration

options.label: B
options.text: The Goodyear rubber company

options.label: C
options.text: A local medical supply company

options.label: D
options.text: A team of engineers at Johns Hopkins University

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to protect the hands of his entire surgical team, including himself.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to use them for a different medical procedure.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to give them away as gifts to his colleagues.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Dr. Halsted's request to the Goodyear rubber company?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They produced a pair of gloves that didn't fit Caroline well.

options.label: C
options.text: They produced a pair of gloves that fit Caroline well and helped her hands recover.

options.label: D
options.text: They produced a different type of medical equipment.

options.label: A
options.text: They became business partners.

options.label: B
options.text: They got married a few months later.

options.label: C
options.text: They remained colleagues but didn't pursue a romantic relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: They went their separate ways.

title: Can you solve the prisoner boxes riddle? - Yossi Elran

multiple-choice.question: A band is trying to find their instruments in 10 boxes. Each musician can look inside any 5 boxes. What is the probability that all 10 musicians will find their instruments if they pick 5 random boxes?
What is the probability of success of the drummer's strategy for 10 musicians?

options.label: A
options.text: Less than 20%

options.label: B
options.text: Around 25%

options.label: C
options.text: Better than 35%

options.label: D
options.text: More than 50%

multiple-choice.question: Why does the drummer's strategy work?

options.label: A
options.text: Because each musician searches all 10 boxes.

options.label: B
options.text: Because each musician starts with the box whose outside matches their instrument and follows a linked sequence.

options.label: C
options.text: Because each musician searches only the first 5 boxes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because each musician searches only the last 5 boxes.

multiple-choice.question: How do the odds of success change as the number of musicians increases?

options.label: A
options.text: The odds of success decrease.

options.label: B
options.text: The odds of success increase.

options.label: C
options.text: The odds of success remain the same.

options.label: D
options.text: The odds of success approach about 30%.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of counting the distinct loops in the simplified case of 4 instruments?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the odds of success.

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the odds of failure.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the number of possible combinations of boxes.

options.label: D
options.text: To visualize the possible paths for each musician.

options.text: Because of their painful sting.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of their distinctive color.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the ant's social behavior.

title: How Americans got stuck with endless drug commercials

multiple-choice.question: Why are prescription drug commercials allowed in the US, but banned in most other countries?

options.label: A
options.text: The US has a more relaxed approach to pharmaceutical marketing.

options.label: B
options.text: The Supreme Court ruled that commercial speech is protected by the 1st and 14th amendments.

options.label: C
options.text: Pharmaceutical companies have more influence in the US.

options.label: D
options.text: The FDA has more lenient regulations in the US.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main barrier that kept prescription drug commercials off TV before 1997?

options.label: A
options.text: FDA regulations requiring ads to include all risk information.

options.label: B
options.text: Pharmaceutical companies' concerns about hurting relationships with doctors.

options.label: C
options.text: The high cost of TV advertising.

options.label: D
options.text: Public opposition to direct-to-consumer ads.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the FDA's clarification on direct-to-consumer ads in 1997?

options.label: A
options.text: Spending on ads decreased significantly.

options.label: B
options.text: Pharmaceutical companies stopped advertising on TV.

options.label: C
options.text: Spending on ads quadrupled by 2004.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of prescription drug commercials on TV remained the same.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a potential negative consequence of direct-to-consumer ads?

options.label: A
options.text: Doctors may be persuaded to prescribe medication to people who don't need it.

options.label: B
options.text: Pharmaceutical companies may lose money on advertising.

options.label: C
options.text: Patients may become more informed about their health options.

options.label: D
options.text: The FDA may have to increase regulations on advertising.

multiple-choice.question: What is an argument in favor of direct-to-consumer ads, according to Sidney Taurel?

options.label: A
options.text: They can educate people about diseases and treatment options.

options.label: B
options.text: They can increase pharmaceutical companies' profits.

options.label: C
options.text: They can reduce the number of people seeking medical treatment.

options.label: D
options.text: They can lead to more accurate diagnoses.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Parkinson's disease

title: What's the ultimate campfire fuel?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between wood and charcoal in terms of their chemical composition?

options.label: A
options.text: Wood is made up of short chains of glucose molecules, while charcoal is made up of long chains.

options.label: B
options.text: Wood is made up of long chains of glucose molecules, while charcoal is made up of mostly carbon.

options.label: C
options.text: Wood is made up of inorganic compounds, while charcoal is made up of organic compounds.

options.label: D
options.text: Wood is made up of volatile gases, while charcoal is made up of non-volatile gases.

options.label: B
options.text: Pyrolysis

options.label: C
options.text: Evaporation

options.label: D
options.text: Condensation

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because the wood is too dense to burn easily.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the wood is too dry to burn easily.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of using charcoal as a fuel source?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces more smoke than wood.

options.label: B
options.text: It releases more heat energy for a longer period of time with fewer smoky byproducts.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more expensive than wood.

options.label: D
options.text: It is less environmentally friendly than wood.

options.label: B
options.text: Air pollution in urban areas.

options.label: C
options.text: Water pollution in industrial areas.

options.label: D
options.text: Climate change.

title: What is a vector? - David Huynh

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between a scalar and a vector quantity?

options.text: A scalar has direction, while a vector has magnitude.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A scalar is used in physics, while a vector is used in mathematics.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are independent of the coordinate system.

options.text: Because they are used in physics.

options.text: Because they are used in mathematics.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To make the vector more complex.

options.label: C
options.text: Vectors

options.label: D

title: Why some of us don't have one true calling - Emilie Wapnick

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about the question "What do you want to be when you grow up?"

options.label: A
options.text: The question is too vague and doesn't provide enough guidance.

options.label: B
options.text: The question is too narrow and implies that people can only have one career or passion.

options.label: C
options.text: The question is too broad and should be more specific.

options.label: D
options.text: The question is unnecessary and shouldn't be asked.

multiple-choice.question: What is a "multipotentialite" according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is only interested in one thing.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is not interested in anything.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone with many interests and creative pursuits.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is only good at one thing.

multiple-choice.question: What is "idea synthesis" according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to come up with new ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to combine two or more fields and create something new at the intersection.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to learn quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to adapt to new situations.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the strengths of being a multipotentialite according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to focus on one thing.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to learn quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to adapt to new situations.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To specialize in one area and become an expert.

options.label: B
options.text: To explore many different interests and passions.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the question "What do you want to be when you grow up?"

options.label: D
options.text: To follow the advice of others.
